We exploit and generalize existing axiomatic and non-­cooperative theories of bilateral bargaining, going back to non-­network based theories of John Nash and Ariel Rubinstein. The broad impact of this project is the potential improvement of allocative efficeincy in arange of network-based markets that operate through bilateral negotaition, and the identfication of settings in which bilateral bargaining over contracts is inefficeint. We extend trembling-hand type equilibrium refinemnet concepts to alternating offer games, and extend axioms for solutions of network-based bilateral bargaining problems.

This project will extend the theory of bilateral contracting in network markets, such as over-the-counter markets for corporate debt and bilateral derivatives including swaps. The goal is to better distinguish conditions, including bargaining protocols, under which bilateral contracting is socially efficient, constrained by the network structure of market relationships and the menus of network-compatible contractible actions. An example is the identification of situations in which contracting between corporations and financial institutions will assign a bankrupt firm's assets to its creditors and swap counterparties in an efficient manner. If not the bankruptcy code should be used to override bilaterally negotiated contractual treatments. Bankruptcy stays can trump rights of termination, collateral, closeout netting, and assignment of insolvency priority. POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome Report

Project Title: Bilateral Contracting in Network Financial Markets 
PI: Darrell Duffie 
Awardee: Stanford University 
NSF Award Number: 1460019
Award Ended: 11/30/2016

 This project extended the theory of bilateral contracting in network markets, such as over-the-counter markets for corporate debt and bilateral derivatives, including swaps. The goal of the project was to better distinguish conditions, including bargaining protocols, under which bilateral contracting is socially efficient, constrained by the network structure of market relationships and the menus of network-compatible contractible actions. 

The main work product is a research paper “Efficient Contracting in Network Financial Markets,” by Darrell Duffie and Chaojun Wang. This paper has been presented at conferences, seminars, and other workshops. It’s first submission to a journal is planned to occur in 2018.

An example application of this project is the identification of situations in which contracting between corporations and financial institutions will assign a bankrupt firm’s assets to its creditors and swap counterparties in an efficient manner.  Cases can be identified in which the bankruptcy code should be used to override bilaterally negotiated contractual treatments.  A bankruptcy stay can trumped by rights of termination, collateral, closeout netting, and assignment of insolvency priority.  Statutes can give courts or insolvency administrators the right to stay contracts at insolvency and to claw back inefficient transfers that occurred prior to insolvency. If bilateral contracting over certain types of is efficient, however, there may be no social benefit, and possibly a social cost, to stay financial contracts in bankruptcy.

The results of this project exploit and generalize existing axiomatic and non-cooperative theories of bilateral bargaining, going back to non-network based theories of John Nash and Ariel Rubinstein. The broad impact of this project is the potential improvement of allocative efficiency in a range of network-based markets that operate through bilateral negotiation, and the identification of settings in which bilateral bargaining over contracts is inefficient.  The results extend trembling-hand refinement concepts to alternating-offers games, and extend axioms for solutions of network-based bilateral bargaining problems.

The project award also supported, through a research assistantship, the development of a young scholar, Chaojun Wang, during the completion of his doctoral studies at Stanford University. Dr. Wang is now an assistant professor at the University of Pennsylvania.
